Well I think they were just trying to say that there is a market for shows and movies about black people and created by black people that can be both popular amongst the general public and with critics as well.
Which is actually a point that needs to be made, as those are artforms that requires funding, and because of that also faith from studios. By proving to studios that movies like Get Out or shows like Atlanta can be successful, we're also giving them incentive to fund more projects like it.
Also, there are actually still a lot of people who doubt the abilities of people based on their gender, sexuality and race, so there is nothing wrong with contradicting that narrative.

Nobody is saying that, Rotten Tomatoes is a review aggregate, so something getting over 90% just means that 90% of critics accounted for on the site reviewed it favourably. So even if the average score is around 7/10, it can still get over 80% on RT.
Also the point the tweet was trying to make wasn't that only black people can create meaningful and great shows and films, but just when given the opportunity black people are also able to make something great.

Potentially, but I also think it is likely that they cheered as a gut reaction to something positive, without getting the time to think about the implications of it. This is a studio audience we're talking about, they're supposed to react in these very simple and highly responsive ways, it really isn't a good representation of the political landscape or the current state of knowledge among the general population.
However, people might still very well be misinformed and lack substantial knowledge about current affairs, but the reaction of the studio audience to a late-night talk show isn't really indicative of anything. So we should never use them to win an argument one way or the other, because if you have legs to stand on you'll find better sources to use.

Right, I know there is evidence that suggest that articles are often shared more times then they are visited, but that doesn't prove that informative and factual articles with clickbait titles are more read (proportionally) than those without.

Not really, because because there are definitely some type of content that is not respectable or objective, and often clickbait titles are biased, Phil has indulged in this himself. If you make a judgement call in the title of the video or in the thumbnail you have already taken away any objectivity there was, because then you have already set a precedent for the rest of the video.

In 2017, Clickbait titles might be the only thing keeping people from making the mistake of reading the headline and thinking they know the whole story.

Because if things change, and you get new information, and you change your opinion based on that you're not flip-flopping, because people should change and adjust their opinions based on facts and critical thinking.

Like I already said, even if someone breaks the law doesn't mean that they did something wrong, and even if they did it should still be dealt with in such a way that benefits as many people as possible. Punishing people for the sake of punishing them is unproductive, ineffective, and a glaring sign of incompetence on the behalf of the people in power.
For an instance if we use the drug analogy, why wouldn't you send drug addicts to rehab instead of giving them to excessively long jail sentences? What is more important here, the rule of law and the principle of it, or making policies and laws that help out as many people as possible?
Also what is even the point of saying you want a discussion if you just want to tell everyone that they are wrong if they disagree with you?

Also they aren't actually disrespecting anyone by illegally immigrating, especially not other citizens. And you can't talk about them as they are only people who only immigrated into one country, because they are also people who immigrated out of another one.

I am a very right winged person. I believe America has our laws and if you come here illegally you aren't respecting them. That's like walking up to someone and punching them in the face and then asking them if you can live with them. It's not right
See the problem is that you are dehumanising undocumented immigrants and implying that they are dangerous people who all should be punished equally. That however isn't really an helpful or productive way to talk about a complex issue, it is piece of rhetoric you use to push people into a corner by implying that people who don't have same opinions as you support punching people in the face. On top of that there are other opitions besides saying that we should just let all illegal immigrants stay or blindly deport all of them.
So while illegal immigration is a problem, I also don't buy into far-right rhetoric that dehumanise large groups of people, and who talk about human beings as if they are not entitled to fair treatment, dignity, and fundamental human rights.
On top of that there are more than one way to deal with the issue, people who live in a country illegally but who haven't commited felonies while in the country should be allowed to become legal citizen. Because there is nothing in it for you to throw them out, beyond satisfying your ideology.
This idea of "it is not right" works nice for a slogan, but it is not at all good for policies. You talk about dealing, but anyone remotely competent knows that there has to be more that one way to deal with drug problems. Because throwing everyone in jail is not at all an effective or helpful method to solve a societal problem.
